H0.text: Increases is the change in pressure that occurs when more gas is added to a rigid container.

H1.text: Occurs is what happens to the pressure when more gas is added to a rigid container.

H2.text: Changes is what happens to the pressure when more gas is added to a rigid container.

H3.text: Higher is the pressure that results when additional gas is added to a rigid container.

A4.text: The ideal gas law, pV = nRT, shows that pressure is directly proportional to the amount of gas (n) when volume is constant.

A5.text: Pressure is calculated as P = (k_B T N)/V, indicating that increasing the number of gas molecules (N) leads to higher pressure when volume and temperature are constant.

A6.text: The pressure is directly proportional to the number of gas particles (N) when volume is constant, as shown by the equation P = (NLF)/V.

A7.text: The pressure is equal to ρv²/3, meaning higher density (due to more gas) increases pressure when volume is constant.
